awd_titl_txt: Cryogenic Wear of Novel High-Entropy Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
Friction and wear are a leading cause of energy loss, inefficiency, and failure in structural alloys, and a scientific understanding of the mechanisms of wear is critical to the design of high performance materials for energy, manufacturing, and infrastructure applications. A new class of alloys known as High Entropy Alloys has recently been found to possess both high strength and the potential for very high wear resistance. This award supports research to determine the fundamental mechanisms of this high wear resistance in two novel High Entropy Alloy compositions. The new knowledge to be gained from this work has the potential to enable the design of high performance materials able to withstand large forces in extreme service environments, including friction and wear at cryogenic temperatures. Students engaged in the research activities will gain valuable educational experience at the undergraduate and graduate level.

The aim of this research project is to examine the hypotheses that the high entropy alloys CoCrFeMnNi and carbon-doped Fe40.4Ni11.3Mn34.8Al7.5Cr6, because of their superior yield strengths compared to stainless steel, will show better wear resistance than stainless steel at 77 K, that that the contacting surfaces of the two alloys will be resistant to phase transformations during dry sliding wear at either room temperature or 77 K, and that the worn surfaces will not exhibit ferromagnetism, whereas austenitic stainless steel AISI 316 will exhibit both of these problems. Dry sliding pin-on-disk wear tests will be performed at both 77 K and 293 K at different sliding velocities and in different environments on these two alloys, and compared to the behavior of 316 stainless steel. The relationship between the microstructure, deformation processes (including material transfer), phase transformations, friction and wear behavior will be determined.  Microstructural characterization of the pre- and post-wear specimens will include transmission electron microscopy, X-ray dispersive spectroscopy; computed-assisted profilometry; X-ray diffraction; nanoindentation; cross-sectional scanning electron microscopy, atom probe tomography; and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
High entropy alloys (HEAs) involve the combination of multiple elements in equal or near equal amounts and have unique properties. Recent research has shown that the mechanical properties of HEAs can be excellent at cryogenic temperatures, making them potential candidates for low-temperature applications such as liquid gas storage, space exploration, cryogenic refrigeration, etc. Liquid lubricants, used to control friction and wear in systems with contacting parts, cannot be used at such low temperatures. Therefore, it is important to develop materials that have good wear resistance at cryogenic temperatures. While many studies have been conducted on the room temperature wear of HEAs, limited research has been done on their cryogenic wear.

The goal of this project was to determine the cryogenic wear behavior of CoCrFeMnNi (referred to as the Cantor HEA) and carbon-doped Fe40.4Ni11.3Mn34.8Al7.5Cr6 (referred to as CHEA). This project determined wear rates, wear mechanisms, and the microstructures resulting from wear of the two HEAs at different sliding velocities (0.1 m/s and 1.0 m/s), in different gaseous environments (air, argon, and nitrogen), and at two different cryogenic temperatures (77 K and 100 K) as well as at room temperature (RT). This work increased understanding of the interaction between the aforementioned parameters and how they affect the wear behavior of the pins in the wear process.

We first designed and constructed our own test rig for the cryogenic wear tests. This rig allowed for both cryogenic friction and wear testing either submerged in liquid nitrogen (wet tests) or in dry sliding conditions in dry nitrogen (dry tests). Tribotests, i.e. tests of friction and wear, were initially performed on 316 stainless steel against yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) disks under both wet and dry cryogenic conditions and compared to its RT behavior. The wear rates of the stainless steel were lower at cryogenic temperatures than at RT. When comparing wear at the different speeds tested, low speed tests had lower wear resistance (greater volume of material removed) than tests run at high speed for all test conditions. Hard, protective oxides, particularly zirconium oxide (ZrO2) from the zirconia disk, were also found in greater quantities on pin surfaces run at high speeds, indicating the influence of speed and surface oxides on wear resistance.

We continued this work through comparing the wear of the CHEA and Cantor HEA against the previously tested 316 stainless steel at RT. Each material was observed under the same low and high sliding speed in air as well as under argon at low speed. The CHEA pins tested at low speed had the lowest wear rate compared to the Cantor HEA and 316 stainless steel. In argon at low speed, all materials exhibited similar wear rates, showing that the environment affects the wear resistance. Similar to the previous study, all three materials showed lower wear rates under high sliding speeds in air. It was determined that the higher pin tip temperatures produced at high sliding speeds cause rapid oxidation of the pin materials. The higher temperature may soften zirconia from the YSZ disk and cause it to easily transfer on the pinhead. Addition of zirconia onto the pinheads can increase wear resistance due to the zirconia?s high hardness. The presence of larger amounts of ZrO2 and other protective oxides on CHEA pin surfaces as well as in its sub-surface regions contributed to CHEA?s greater wear resistance compared to the other materials.

Both the dry and wet sliding wear behaviors of the CHEA and Cantor HEA pins were also  determined under cryogenic temperatures. Like the RT tests, the CHEA pins experienced lower wear rates compared to the Cantor HEA pins due to more protective surface and sub-surface oxides. An interesting observation is that RT tests had much higher wear rates at low-speed while cryogenic tests had higher wear rates at high-speed. Cryogenic tests run under high sliding speeds saw larger patches of material removed than in RT tests, indicating less adherent oxides formed under this speed at low temperature. Greater particle build-up and ZrO2 amounts on the pin surface was found for the cryogenic low-speed tests. These features could have improved its wear resistance over RT tests at the same speed.

Through our experimental investigation, we found that the CHEA?s wear resistance was generally better than both the Cantor HEA and 316 stainless steel under both RT and cryogenic temperatures. The CHEA?s better wear resistance is attributed to the protective surface oxides that form during wear. Although the CHEA under cryogenic temperatures did not perform better than at RT under all conditions, a greater understanding of its wear mechanisms under the tested parameters was developed.

The results from this work have been published and presented through conference talks and student poster presentations. Several graduate students, undergraduates, and a postdoc were trained and involved in the process of conducting this research.


Last Modified: 10/03/2023
Modified by: Ian Baker
